article.description: Dwayne Collins scored 14 points to lead No. 17 Miami to a 70-60 win over Southern Mississippi on Friday in the Paradise Jam opener.
article.headline: Hurdle's 13 points, clutch 3-pointer carry Miami past Southern Miss
article.linkText: No. 16 Miami thwarts Southern Miss behind Hurdle
article.story: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, U.S. Virgin Islands -- Miami got a spark from an unexpected source at the Paradise Jam on Friday. Senior guard Lance Hurdle, who missed the Hurricanes' season opener with a high ankle sprain, returned to the lineup to give them 13 points on 3-for-5 shooting from the field in a 70-60 win over Southern Mississippi. "It's great to be back with my teammates. ... " Hurdle said. "The adrenaline was flowing. I felt like a kid on Christmas." Hurdle's 22 minutes of play included a clutch 3-pointer at the first-half buzzer to give the Hurricanes (No. 16 ESPN/USA Today, No. 17 AP) a 36-24 lead at the University of the Virgin Islands. Grinning widely, Hurdle jogged backward as the buzzer blared and his jubilant teammates crowded around him on the way to the locker room. "Lance Hurdle -- his play was crucial," said Miami coach Frank Haith, adding that his team did a good job keeping the Golden Eagles out of the paint. Dwayne Collins added 14 points and nine rebounds for Miami (2-0), which hadn't played Southern Miss (2-1) since the Hurricanes' 85-78 win on Feb. 26, 1957. The Golden Eagles outrebounded the Hurricanes 35-33, but Miami shot 44.7 percent from the floor while holding Southern Miss to 39 percent in a game that had three lead changes and two ties. Senior guard Jack McClinton had 13 points for Miami, but Haith said he was "pressing" too much. "We'll see normal Jack here pretty soon," said Haith, who has led the Canes to three postseason appearances in four seasons. Miami, which entered the season with its highest preseason ranking, took a 15 point-lead with 4:37 remaining and never looked back. Junior guard Jeremy Wise led Southern Miss with 21 points, and Courtney Beasley added 14 points. Golden Eagles coach Larry Eustachy did not speak to reporters after the game. Assistant Steve Barnes said the coaches were "disappointed in our lack of execution and our defensive breakdowns." Miami, which has its best AP ranking since they were No. 17 on Feb. 18, 2002, will next play the winner of Friday night's game between No. 2 Connecticut and La Salle. Southern Miss will take on the loser. Haith said he looked forward to possibly taking on No. 2 Connecticut. "It would be a tremendous opportunity," Haith said. "But we look forward to whoever we play."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
